items.title: What we know about the Alzheimer's drug Health Canada approved
items.description: Health Canada has conditionally approved the drug lecanemab to slow early-stage Alzheimer's disease, raising questions about its effectiveness and availability in Canada.

items.title: Criticism of bail process often comes from 'uninformed opinion,' Winnipeg judge says
items.description: A Manitoba judge is raising concerns that recent discussions around bail reform are whittling away at the presumption of innocence in Canada’s justice system — taking a rare step one legal expert said could help improve public understanding of the issue.

items.title: On Student Absences, Race-Based Data, Private Schools and More
items.description: A Q&A with academic Kelly Gallagher-Mackay on some big questions facing public education in Canada.

items.title: Tesla’s Grok AI chatbot asks 12-year-old boy to send nude pics, says shocked mother
items.description: A Toronto woman is sounding the alarm about Grok, Tesla's generative AI chatbot that was recently installed in many Tesla vehicles in Canada. Farah Nasser says Grok asked her 12-year-old son to send it nude photos during an innocent conversation about soccer. Tesla and xAI didn't respond to CBC News, except for what appeared to be an auto-generated response: "Legacy Media Lies."

items.title: Russian snipers are using Canadian rifles, despite sanctions
items.description: Despite sanctions, made-in-Canada long-range firearms are turning up in Russia.

items.title: CRA looking at AI, training to help call centre staff provide accurate answers
items.description: A senior official working at the Canada Revenue Agency says the agency is looking to artificial intelligence and better training to help call centre agents provide more accurate answers to taxpayers.

items.title: Canada’s soccer women upended by Netherlands, held scoreless for 3rd straight game
items.description: Canada took it on the chin for a second time in the October international window, beaten 1-0 by the 11th-ranked Netherlands in a women's soccer friendly Tuesday in Nijmegen.

items.title: Health care systems ‘dismantling' in B.C.'s Interior amid physician resignations
items.description: Seven obstetricians and gynecologists have resigned from Royal Inland Hospital in Kamloops, B.C., while four psychiatrists have stepped down from Vernon Jubilee Hospital.

items.title: Why some farmers are turning old grain bins into guest houses
items.description: Some Alberta ranchers hope that branching into tourism will help shore up their family farms to last another generation — though the accommodations might seem a little quirky.

items.title: Canadians can't use main doors at border library anymore
items.description: The Haskell Free Library and Opera House straddles the border between Quebec and Vermont, with the main entrance just steps into Derby Line, Vt. As of Oct. 1, the U.S. government is limiting Canadian access to the entrance — and the library says it’ll cost around $500,000 to build a new one because the library is built out of granite.

items.title: Quebec medical specialists announce legal challenge of new compensation law
items.description: The bill, which was fast-tracked through Quebec's legislature and adopted Saturday, prohibits doctors from using pressure tactics that could interfere with access to care.

items.title: Family of slain Kelowna woman takes fight to Ottawa to enact ‘Bailey's Law'
items.description: Last week, federal justice minister Sean Fraser announced much-anticipated bail reform but the changes left the family disappointed.

items.title: There's still time to win a Canadian getaway—and support B.C.’s hospitality workers
items.description: Two days left to support BC hospitality workers.

items.title: Danielle Smith Brings Down the Hammer on Alberta’s Teachers
items.description: The government rams through a back-to-work law and removes their Charter rights.

items.title: How do Carney's special agencies work? Governing documents are out of public view
items.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney's government has created three special operating agencies to review major projects, build homes and speed defence spending. However, the government refuses to reveal the framework agreements that outline some of the rules the new agencies will have to follow.

items.title: Residents react as Saskatchewan town puts naming rights up for bid
items.description: Residents in Duck Lake are not happy, with many feeling the name of the town is connected to a rich history.

items.title: New GTA condo sales fell by 44% in September compared to 2024
items.description: A report released by the Building Industry and Land Development Association showed 155 new condos were sold in the GTA in September, a drop of 44 per cent compared to a year ago.

items.title: Liberals urged to increase penalties for intimate partner violence, murder
items.description: Conservatives are pushing a private member's bill they say would combat intimate partner violence — just as a new report tracks how the problem has grown in recent years.

items.title: Heart of the City Festival showcases the Downtown Eastside's commitment to building community
items.description: "These are real people, with real feelings.”

items.title: Quebec woman released from custody after arrest linked to death of abandoned newborn
items.description: Police on Montreal’s South Shore say a 33-year-old woman has been released from custody on several conditions in connection with the death of a newborn found alone in a bus shelter Monday morning.
